V.  i,  16,  under Augustus or Tiberius ) must be due to the addition of some board of five,  which the author rightly refuses to identify with the Ephors or Nomophylakes.  Her suggestion that they were the five associate Patronomoi,  excluding the eponymous mos of the year,  is most unfortunate,  for it ignores the definite evidence of two inscriptions that their number was six^.  This enlarged body,  however it may have been composed,  is presumably the avva^xla mentioned in a few inscriptions of the period Hadrian - Caracalla,  but it affords no confirmation for the statement of Pausanias that Cleomenes III.  instituted the Patronomoi,  though the author may well be right in ascribing to the same reforms the replacement of the chief Ephor by the Patronomos as the eponymous magistrate. 
The duties of the Patronomoi and other magistrates are carefully examined,  and defined as far as the scanty evidence permits.  The theory of a board of Epimeletai is rightly rejected,  as is the view that election was based on tribal representation.  The conclusion regarding the Tribes,  drawn from the evidence of the Sphaireis - inscriptions,  is that in the Roman period there were only four Phylai,  for which Obai was at that date a synonym ; and that they were wholly athletic organisations »unconnected with the citizen - body except in so far as the state directly controlled the activities of the Epheboi 41.  ( This is loosely expressed,  for the Sphaireis are elsewhere defined as having already ceased to be Epheboi [ p.  132 ].  ) If,  however,  there were only four Phylai competing in the ball - game encounters,  the author has not considered how it was possible for one team to draw a bye,  as must have happened to account for the special credit attaching to a team winning àvé<peÔQoi.
